item.title: 04/06/2022 - Free Software (Free as in Freedom);
item.author: Benjamin
item.description:
04/06/22 - Free Software (Free as in Freedom);

Hello! Now when I say Linux what is the first thing that comes to mind? Sweaty nerds? Angry elitists? Well, I see a group of dedicated people rallying around the idea of Free Software. Well OK fine I also see some sweaty nerds and angry elitiests too. When I say Free Software I don't mean free as in price (however the software is also free in price) but free as in Freedom meaning the software can be run, edited, contributed to, and freely shared.

The Free Software Foundation (FSF) is a non-profit founded by Richard Stallman in 1985, FSF's most know project is the GNU operating system used in tandem with the Linux Kernel to become GNU/Linux. If you look at software development over the years you can see that Open Source software has become more popular however Open Source and Free Software should not be confused with each other. An Open Source program can still be Proprietary. Take for example Microsoft Visual Studio Code, now in the past Microsoft has been harsh on Open Source software (going so far as to call Linux communism) however in 2015 Microsoft announced and released VS Code as an Open Source lightweight (compared to the normal visual studio) code editor, but did you read that? Open Source? and Microsoft? Impossible. Well, your wrong here is the VS Code GitHub page (Microsoft owns GitHub... just to let you know). Ok well, that's all well and good, Microsoft released an Open Source program so what? Well if you go and download VS Code something might seem off. You see VS Code is licensed under the MIT Licence meaning anyone can use the code for commercial use, they can distribute it, or modify it. Ok, that's good, right? Anyone can do anything with the code. Well... most people just download the binaries from Microsoft's website however when Microsoft builds the binary the program is licensed under a Proprietary license. huh. Well, that's scummy. If VS Code was released under a GPL license then this would never happen (the GPL license was created by the Free Software Foundation).

Ok, why should you care about Free Software? Well with Proprietary software you are giving up your freedom and possibly privacy if the company built any spyware into their software (or os). Ok, so what alternatives should you use instead of Proprietary software? Well just look them up yourself, but if you cannot be bothered here's some: instead of Microsoft Office use LibreOffice, instead of Photoshop use GIMP (GNU Image Manipulation Program), instead of using VLC use... well actually VLC is Free Software so its fine. If you wan't to look more into it here is a link to the Free Software Directory.

Now should you change your entire OS in the name of Free Software? I mean if you are that dedicated to Free Software then yes you should probably use something like GNU/Linux or maybe even OpenBSD. Now listen I'm not like some Linux users, I'm not going to start yelling at you to "StARt UsiNg GNu+LinUX beCauSE WinDblOWS 11 SuXX aND is MAdE bY MiCro$OfT (akA SAtaN)" because believe it or not I have better things to do (surprisingly). And also to any people who are actually like that please watch this video, it is very important. Ok let's get back on track, if you don't use Linux or just haven't tried it then just look around at different distros for example maybe Fedora Linux, you don't even need to flash a USB and boot into it to try it out, you can make a Virtual Machine with Virtual Box or use DistroTest.net. Just give it a try... please :).

Well, that is all I have to say, remember to add my RSS feed the button is at the top, Email me if you have any questions at contact@sevengames.xyz, and here is my PGP Key.

item.title: 05/06/22 - The Onion Router;
item.author: Benjamin
item.description:
05/06/22 - The Onion Router;

When you go to any website on the internet there is a very high chance that you are probably being tracked. By who? Everyone, mainly Big Tech e.g. Facebook, Google, and Amazon. Let's focus on Google, they are mainly an advertising company that sells user data. You may think that they might just sell what videos people watch on YouTube or people's Google search terms but it goes much deeper than that. Google allows people to have advertisements placed on their sites so the person can get profit, however, the advertisements can be used to track what website a user is on even if it is not owned by Google itself. But how can people stop Google from prying into their personal life more than that person wants? Well, many people point at VPNs which if you aren't as that pressed about privacy is a very good idea. However, the way to get a VPN is not so private, the best VPN that you could get if you are interested in keeping your privacy would probably be Mullvad, you don't need any personal information such as emails to create an account and payment is very secure, you can use Monero or just send in cash... like real money. You put it in an envelope along with a special code that is associated with your account then you send that envelope in the mail.

So is Mullvad the best way to stay private online? No. It's not the absolute best way. It will still keep your IP address private if that's all you want but if you want however if you want to go beyond that then there is something far better than that. The Onion Router more commonly known as Tor (spelled as Tor, not TOR) uses a technique called Onion Routing where requests are encased in several layers of encryption and sends it through a series of relays which one by one "peels" back a layer, uncovering the data's next destination. After the final relay removes the final layer it sends it onto the site you are trying to access with no knowledge of who sent the message/request.

The History

Onion routing was originally developed in the mid-1990s at the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory by Paul Syverson, Michael Reed, and David Goldschlag. It was originally made the protect U.S. intelligence communications online. In 2002 Roger Dingledine and Nick Mathewson joined Paul Syverson in 2002 to develop the largest best-known implementation of onion routing called 'The Onion Routing project' or the Tor Project.

The main implementation of onion routing is in web browsing by using the Tor Browser. The Tor Browser is built off of a modification of the Firefox browser that changes default settings to be more privacy respecting. And as you can guess it sends all traffic through the Tor network. With this, your IP address is changed and websites can no longer use that to track you and it is much more anonymous than using a VPN as with one the VPN provider can still see what website you go to, with Tor exit nodes they can only see what websites a user is going to but not what user is accessing them. The major downside to Tor is the speed because your connection is being routed through several different nodes on different continents this means that the speed is much slower than a VPN.

How do you use Tor?

Firstly go to https://torproject.org/ and download the Tor Browser for the platform you are on. Then install it... then launch it... the connect... then that's it. You can access the internet as normal in addition to Onion Sites/Hidden Services.

Are you completely Anonymous using Tor?

No, you are not. Tor cannot make you fully anonymous but some ways can help you. For example, go into the Tor Browser settings and then select the safest security option. This will disable some fonts/icons and Javascript. But why is that important?

Fingerprinting.

Not only your IP can be used to track you but the settings on your browser can be used to do this too. It is called browser fingerprinting and it is a technique of getting any piece of information from your browser however small that can link you between websites, that information might be how large your screen is, the Operating System you are using, the extensions installed on your web browser, the fonts installed on your computer and so much more. When using Tor Browser it masks everything for example saying that every user uses Windows and they use Firefox to make every user look the same so that fingerprinting is much harder. And by turning off Javascript most of the fingerprinting techniques can be avoided as the websites you are connecting to can no longer see the individual details that make you unique. There are several fingerprint testers online for example https://coveryourtracks.eff.org/.

Isn't Tor illegal?

No... well, it depends. If you live in China then Tor is blocked meaning people in China cannot use the Tor Network however, this can be circumvented with Bridges. If you live in a place like the US or the UK then Tor is not illegal. But I know that you might be saying "isn't there illegal sites on Tor?". Yes, there are illegal sites on Tor just like there are Illegal sites on the Clear Web.

What is the difference between the Clear Web and a Hidden Service?

If you noticed when I was talking about how Tor works you saw that all the traffic was encrypted until it gets sent out to the website you are trying to access (the traffic is still being encrypted if the site is using HTTPS however if the site is using HTTP then the exit node can see the contents of whatever you are sending). So using Tor with the clear web can be dangerous, however what if the requests always stay inside the Tor network? Then it would always be encrypted until it gets to the website so not a single relay can see what content the traffic holds only you and the website you are accessing. This is what a Hidden Service is, a website that can only be accessed by Tor. They are also more commonly called Onion Sites. You can tell when you are on an onion site because the padlock in the upper right of the Tor Browser will become the Tor Browser logo and also the URL will look something like: http://ojdu6jltlecc5m24wtyou654frwyendjbkfqipp6tcgphgl53tjkqiyd.onion/.

Well, it won't look something like that... because it is exactly like that. That is my onion side. But why do I run an onion site? Because I believe that no one should be tracked and monitored on the internet and even though probably no one will care about the onion site because no one who cares about that would be reading this I still think it is important. Do I use Tor? Yes. For general internet browsing, I use the Tor Browser, however, for something more personal such as school work or Amazon. I would use another web browser like Firefox.

Any that's just what I think. If you think any different or want to ask a question then contact me at my email contact@sevengames.xyz. Make sure to encrypt it with my PGP key and send your PGP public key with the email.

item.title: 06/06/22 - UK Time;
item.author: Benjamin
item.description:
06/06/22 - UK Time;

Ok, so right now, the UK is on BST (British Summer Time) which is 1 hour ahead of GMT (Greenwich Mean Time), and that itself is very strange because the country that has Greenwich is one hour ahead of it. But what annoys me about it is everything, today I saw an ad for Summer Game Fest and it has the time for the event in GMT which reminded me of the same event a year ago where there was another advertisement which showed the time in GMT but me being a dumbass I did not realize that the UK has changed to BST so then came the time of the event YouTube did its countdown thing then when it finished an image showing the information of the event was shown, for 15 minutes I was confused because the time the event started and the current time were the same... except where it said GMT next it, when I realized the UK was in BST I felt quite dumb, which I am. Also, BST ends at the end of October for some reason despite it not being summer at that time.

Another annoying thing is the RSS, whenever I need to add a new RSS item for the feed on this website I have to put the time in as GMT. Anyway, that's it, that's all I wanted to say about the UK time zone, I know why they change it to summertime but especially for the first couple of months it confuses me. Well, it just confuses me, don't know about anyone else.

item.title: 10/07/22 - I host Instances now!;
item.author: Benjamin
item.description:
You can read can't you? It's right up there if you can't tell. I now host public instances for several different project. But what is an Instance? Well in short when you go onto a site, for example let's say Reddit alot of information is being logged, on the official Reddit website your IP address, User-agent, Browser, Operating System, any referal links, the device ID, pages visited, links clicked, search terms, and more are being collected by a company that deletes anything that does not live up to the "Wholesome 100" look that they want.

So let's say you want to use Reddit but don't want the Big Keanu Chungus Reeves company to know anything about you. Well then you are in luck. There are several projects such as Teddit and Libreddit that provides an "alternative front-end" to these sites and don't share you presonal information.
So I have some of these project and set them up so that anyone can use them. Of course these things cost money so if you like my instances why not donate? Yes I have a donation page no I don't care... I like money.

SearXNG;

SearXNG is a metasearch engine which basicly means it takes results from other search engines such as Google and DuckDuckGo and presents them to the user. On top of that it is also privacy-respecting, well as privacy-respecting as the search engines you have enabled are.

I think that metasearch engines are much better then normal search engines because some search engines do things much better than others so instead of having to go to different websites to get the link you want you can just use one site.

Repo: https://github.com/searxng/searxng
Link: https://searx.sevengames.xyz



Libreddit;

10 second pitch: Libreddit is a portmanteau of "libre" (meaning freedom) and "Reddit". It is a private front-end like Invidious but for Reddit. Browse the coldest takes of r/unpopularopinion without being tracked.

  • 🚀 Fast: written in Rust for blazing-fast speeds and memory safety

  • ☁️ Light: no JavaScript, no ads, no tracking, no bloat

  • 🕵️ Private: all requests are proxied through the server, including media

  • 🔒 Secure: strong Content Security Policy prevents browser requests to Reddit


Yes I did steal that directly from their GitHub repo.


Repo: https://github.com/spikecodes/libreddit
Link: https://libreddit.sevengames.xyz



Invidious;

Invidious is an open source privacy-respecting alternative front-end to YouTube. If you've read the previous instances descriptions then you know what this is. It allows users to view YouTube videos without going to the YouTube site. Invidious is better than regluar YouTube not because is not owned by Google but because it is a lightweight site that just works... well and because it's not owned by Google.


Repo: https://github.com/iv-org/invidious
Link: https://invidious.sevengames.xyz



Nitter;

Now reading the previous descriptions would you beleve if I told you that Nitter is an open source, fast, lightweight, privacy-respecting front-end for Twitter? You know the gist by now. Blah blah Twitter bad blah blah no JavaScript.


Repo: https://github.com/zedeus/nitter
Link: https://nitter.sevengames.xyz




As of right now those are all the instances I have running. Hopefully in the future I can have more running such as ProxiTok and Bibliogram.

I'm going to write more Blogs in the future, right now I am thinking about OpenBSD. I used it for like a week and have some things to say about it.
